"The powerful Webb telescope doesn't need to take pretty pictures to revolutionize our grasp of the cosmos," he said.

The James Webb Space Telescope "just scored another first: a molecular and chemical portrait of a distant world's skies."

While Webb and other space telescopes, including the NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope, have previously revealed isolated ingredients of this heated planet's atmosphere, the new readings provide a full menu of atoms, molecules, and even signs of active chemistry and clouds.... The telescope's array of highly sensitive instruments was trained on the atmosphere of WASP-39 b, a "hot Saturn" orbiting a star some 700 light-years away...

Earlier Mashable explained that the researchers "wait for planets to travel in front of their bright stars. This starlight passes through the exoplanet's atmosphere, then through space, and ultimately into instruments called spectrographs aboard Webb... essentially hi-tech prisms, which separate the light into a rainbow of colors. Here's the big trick: Certain molecules, like water, in the atmosphere absorb specific types, or colors, of light."

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
The findings bode well for the capability of Webb's instruments to conduct the broad range of investigations of exoplanets — planets around other stars — hoped for by the science community. That includes probing the atmospheres of smaller, rocky planets like those in the TRAPPIST-1 system.... Among the unprecedented revelations is the first detection in an exoplanet atmosphere of sulphur dioxide, a molecule produced from chemical reactions triggered by high-energy light from the planet's parent star.... "This is the first time we have seen concrete evidence of photochemistry — chemical reactions initiated by energetic stellar light — on exoplanets," he said

This led to another first: scientists applying computer models of photochemistry to data that require such physics to be fully explained. The resulting improvements in modelling will help build the technological know-how needed to interpret potential signs of habitability in the future.... The planet's proximity to its host star — eight times closer than Mercury is to our Sun — also makes it a laboratory for studying the effects of radiation from host stars on exoplanets. Better knowledge of the star-planet connection should bring a deeper understanding of how these processes affect the diversity of planets observed in the galaxy.

Other atmospheric constituents detected by the Webb telescope include sodium (Na), potassium (K), and water vapour (H2O), confirming previous space- and ground-based telescope observations as well as finding additional fingerprints of water, at these longer wavelengths, that haven't been seen before. Webb also saw carbon dioxide (CO2) at higher resolution, providing twice as much data as reported from its previous observations...

>>15013961
the word "quantum" comes from the word "Lichtkvant", i.e. a "quantum of light", the original word for "photon"
the word "quantum" essentially means "amount", and refers to how photons have discrete "amounts" of energy due to how the systems emitting and absorbing photons operate at specific energy states
however, at the very fundamental level the systems are in fact not quantized, but continuous wavefunctions, the quantized qualities are rather abstractions that arise due to localized waveforms, whether transient or enduring
>«Integers are not inputs of the [quantum] theory, as Bohr thought [Danish physicist Niels Bohr “implemented” discreteness at the atomic scale]. They are outputs. The integers are an example of what physicists call an emergent quantity. In this view, the term “quantum mechanics” is a misnomer. Deep down, the theory is not quantum. In systems such as the hydrogen atom, the processes described by the theory mold discreteness from underlying continuity.»
>—David Tong, theoretical physicist at the University of Cambridge

threads.com:
why is it the case that future rolls are not influenced by previous rolls, yet streaks are still unlikely?
as in, flipping a coin. the chances are 50/50 every time, but if I land heads 10 times in a row, is it not reasonable to say "it would be very unlikely to hit heads 11 times in a row"?
or is it that it doesnt matter. it would be unlikely to hit 11 heads in a row just randomly, but if you just happen to do 10 in a row, you've got a 50% chance to do 11 on the next one?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>15015544
>why is it the case that future rolls are not influenced by previous rolls, yet streaks are still unlikely?
Probability of a roll = p. Probability of a streak of n rolls = p^n

>is it not reasonable to say "it would be very unlikely to hit heads 11 times in a row"?
No, since 10 heads have already occurred, there's a 50% chance of getting an 11th. You're confusing the probability of getting 11 heads before any heads have occurred (0.5^11) with the probability after the unlikely event of 10 of them having already occurred.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: Infinite sets don't exist or don't have a cardinality
threads.com:
The idea that two infinite sets can have the same cardinality because you can establish a one-to-one correspondence between its members is contradictory since you can also establish a one-to-every-two correspondence, a one-to-every-three, ... , one-to-every-n correspondence. All of which would tell you the two sets have different cardinalities because guess what, since the set isn't finite, you don't know what the last number is, hence you can't really say by mapping one element to every other element you will be able to map all elements or not.

For example, take the set of even natural numbers E and the set of natural numbers N. Set theory books would have you believe that because you can connect the 1st element of E with the 1st element of N, the 2nd of E with the 2nd of N, and so on, that means you established a one-to-one correspondence, and so E and N must have the same cardinality. The problem is that you don't really know if you really able to do that for all elements since you don't know what the last element is. Further, since cardinality is a determined size, an infinite set cannot possible have a cardinality, thus leading to contradictions if you try to compare their non-existence cardinalities as you shall soon see.

Now, instead of mapping the 1st element of E with the 1st element of N, the 2nd of E with the 2nd of N, and so on, map the 1st element of E with the 2nd element of N, the 2nd of E with the 4th of N, the 3rd element of E with the 6th element of N, and so on. By the same reasoning of the "same cardinality via one-to-one correspondence", this should lead you to conclude that E has half the cardinality of N.

No. Sound intensity is proportional to power output. You can design speakers with the same diameter but higher power outputs and thus be louder. I'm not familiar with any limit on the power output of a device. I guess if it's too high the speaker breaks.

Your question is then to ask what's the maximum frequency at which the speaker can vibrate, as this gives you its maximum energy (an by extension maximum intensity and maximum sound intensity).

The maximum frequency at which the speaker vibrates is a function of the material itself and will likely depend on some kind of shear modulus for elastic deformation. So, find the material with the strongest resistance to deformations, make that into a speaker. Calculate or estimate the maximum frequency at which it can vibrate and you got your answer.

last_replies.com:
>>15014892
Repeatedly square a matrix.
Sum of top row divided by sum of bottom row should give the approximation.
[math]\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2\\ 1 & 1\end{bmatrix} = 3/2\\
\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2\\ 1 & 1\end{bmatrix}^2 = \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 4\\ 2 & 3\end{bmatrix} = 7/5 \\
\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2\\ 1 & 1\end{bmatrix}^4 = \begin{bmatrix} 17 & 24\\ 12 & 17\end{bmatrix} = 41/29 \\
\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2\\ 1 & 1\end{bmatrix}^8 = \begin{bmatrix} 577 & 816\\ 408 & 577\end{bmatrix} = 1393/985[/math]

1393/985 should be good enough.
Each squaring should roughly double the number of correct digits.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>15015799
You get the matrix by starting with:
x^2 = 2 then adding a*x to both sides to get
x^2 + ax = ax + 2.
x(x+a) = ax + 2 gives
x = (ax+2)/(x+a)
The matrix I used corresponds to a=1.
Iterating f(x) = (x+2)/(x+1) should converge to sqrt(2) if the initial point is chosen close to sqrt(2).
I just used x = 1 to keep it simple.

>being about as smart as Kurt Gödel or thrice that
Let's look at that for sec. What does it mean to thrice Godel's abilities?

or rather How do I quantify what went on Godels head to produce the end result? Was it anything like a machine? Was the system one system of commands or a nebulous and ever changing track?

I'm not saying Godel wasn't a bio-robot like the rest of us, I'm saying the speed and utility of a function vs flops is not what was going on in his head. Its going on the "heads" of things that sort images, or things that match wave-forms, or things that pare words and concepts down and assign a likelihood, but not in the heads of mathematicians, classically trained musicians, physicists, or anyone else we consider "intelligent."

For all we know, when Godel thought of certain functions, he saw the leaves changing on a tree from when he first encountered those functions at school. Lets say this seemingly unrelated mental episode was CRITICAL towards the output that we recognize as genius, or even just generally intelligent.

How are we to code for that? Isn't there the least chance that we've confused ability with utility and that what we're trying to achieve is not even possible in the design space we occupy? I'm saying that I believe (more like I'm certain, but that would make for a boring argument) that you can't network Einsteins as though they were servers, not in the traditional way we understand increasing logical function. There's something very illogical about the thought processes that lead to brilliance, or even just function, and we may can never hope to code for it, no matter how ultimately computational the underlying process.

>>15011675
The distinction you are describing is that between the unarguably non-invasive senses (hearing, seeing) and between the maximally invasive senses (touch, taste) on the other side.

The distinction matters because we are animals. The concept of being felt up by an external actor being cost-free for the actor is antithetical to your prime directive, which is staying alive. There needs to be some cost involved. After munging this concept enough you arrive at the outcome that animals evolve in a way that does not make it advantageous or possible for touch to work as a zero-cost (especially zero entry cost) "pleasure dispenser". Same with taste, but also other reasons (not dying to toxins etc. And a static taste is good for that.).

Smell is the strangest and perhaps the most analog and least digital sense, compared to hearing/vision which 100% are just digital. And no, I don't mean digital as in fingers, of course.

last_replies.com: Draw a line between the points of the circles opposite from the points of intersection, and let A be the midpoint of this line. Since the total length of A is 2 * (radius 1 + radius 2), it follows that the distance from center 1 to A is radius 2, and the distance from center 2 to A is radius 1. As the points travel around the circle with the same radial speed, they trace out the drawn triangles. Angle B is always the same, and from the observation about distances from A to centers, they are always similar triangles. Therefore the distances from the travelling points to A are always the same.

Nutrients are a key component of maintaining good health in space. But fresh produce is in short supply on the space station compared with the prepackaged meals astronauts eat during their six-month stays in low-Earth orbit.

"It is fairly important to our exploration goals at NASA to be able to sustain the crew with not only nutrition but also to look at various types of plants as sources for nutrients that we would be hard-pressed to sustain on the long trips between distant destinations like Mars and so forth," said Kirt Costello, chief scientist at NASA's International Space Station Program and a deputy manager of the ISS Research Integration Office.

Astronauts have grown and tasted different types of lettuce, radishes and chiles on the International Space Station. Now, the crew members can add some dwarf tomatoes — specifically, Red Robin tomatoes — to their list of space-grown salad ingredients. The experiment is part of an effort to provide continuous fresh food production in space.... The space tomatoes will be grown inside small bags called plant pillows installed in the Vegetable Production System, known as the Veggie growth chamber, on the space station. The astronauts will frequently water and nurture the plants....

The hardware is still in development for larger crop production on the space station and eventually other planets, but scientists are already planning what plants might grow best on the moon and Mars. Earlier this year, a team successfully grew plants in lunar soil that included samples collected during the Apollo missions. "Tomatoes are going to be a great crop for the moon," Massa said. last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>15012237

The good news is it's manageable.

Write down all tasks you're planning or worry about (no exceptions) on a piece of paper you can put in your pocket. Record all commitments in a calendar, with frequent reminders for each. Keep your working area completely clean, both physically and digitally (desktop icons hidden, windows maximized). Record any tasks you think of immediately, and return to what you were doing. Revisit your list to pick which tasks you'll attempt at the beginning of each day. Live a life of minimalism, otherwise everything will feel like an endless mess of things to organize and clean. Etc, you get the idea.

You have to put these structures in place as soon as you can and stick to them for the rest of your life.

Read the original GTD book by David Allen. That is, if the disorder hasn't completely compromised your reading ability.

Personally, I'd already been down this path, made every adjustment and compensation possible, spent years in therapy, and completely turned my life around. But even still, after a while things ended up going to complete shit and even worse than before.

I swore off drugs too (prescription stimulants) until I had exhausted every other option, which was a serious mistake. My life would have been much less stressful and far more fulfilling had I been medicated sooner. Just my experience tho, like >>15012660 you can always try them and stop them when you want, unlike with antidepressents.

I have experience using mantras as originally intended, as a meditative tool to direct the mind

None of this western subliminals bullshit though, traditional mantras from eastern traditions, Sanskrit mostly, some Tibetan and Gurmukhi

Aum Mani Padme Hum

Heart mantra: Aum gate gate paragate parasamgate bodhi svaha

Gayatri mantra

Tara mantra: Aum tare tutture ture soha - this ig invokes a buddhist deity, enjoy the melody though

Not sure about whatever tortured and deluded goal you have of self improvement; but I find these very effective in soothing and calming my mind and allowing me to consider situations with equanimity.

Now that's only because you study math through a book which already has symbols etc. If you were to "discover" such concepts on your own you would have already started to build intuition and then established some symbols/definitions.
Anyways my point is if something doesn't feel intuitive in maths you must work more on it. Calculus and (real) analysis should be really intuitive for example.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>15014750
You're thinking of light as a stream of particles. On the scales applied here, you need to think of it as an electric field consisting of positive and negative regions. The electric field gradients between the + and - regions can trap a dielectric particle via the electric force. (The magnetic aspect of the beam can be ignored as it plays no role.)
Ashkin wasn't the first to come up with this idea, contrary to what the politics of science often claims:
Propulsion and Angular Stabilization of Dust Particles in a Laser Cavity. (Journal of Applied Physics 38, 5290 (1967)). A. D. May, E. G. Rawson, and E. H. Hara.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>15013310
Actual medfag here

Urine that directly exists the kidney through the ureters is normally sterile, urine is actually just filtered blood, all things in the urine were in the blood at some point. Urine in the bladder is also sterile.

However when urine exits through the urethra it picks up bacteria lining the inner surface of the urethra, so urine that exists the body is not sterile so there is indeed a possibility of bacteremia (which may lead to sepsis and septic shock if the bacterial dose is high enough) if you reinject the urine back. If the catheter in picrel was inserted to the bladder then the urine coming out would probably be sterile.

Now other than bacteremia, the effects of IV urine are going to be similar to uremia (see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uremia)
Sterile IV urine would probably result in metabolic acidosis (due to low pH of urine), electrolyte disturbances (particularly dangerous is potassium leading to hyperkalemia which could result in cardiac arrest, in fact i suspect this is what will kill you first) and also probably some form of encephalopathy due to high concentration of urea.
